articles.headline: Disney Drags the Beach Blanket Out of the Attic and Gives It a Shake
articles.snippet: The Disney Channel is hoping the silly, surfing, singing characters in its new “Teen Beach Movie” catch on with young viewers.
articles.abstract: The Disney Channel is hoping the silly, surfing, singing characters in its new “Teen Beach Movie” catch on with young viewers.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Next month Disney Channel’s young viewers will be introduced to a movie genre — the beach party film — that hasn’t been popular since their grandparents were teenagers.

articles.headline: Housing Market Shrugging Off Rise in Mortgage Rates
articles.snippet: The Case-Shiller home price index showed its largest gain since early 2006, and the rate of new home sales reached its quickest pace since July 2008.
articles.abstract: The Case-Shiller home price index showed its largest gain since early 2006, and the rate of new home sales reached its quickest pace since July 2008.
articles.lead_paragraph: Mortgage rates may be inching up, but they have not put a damper on the American housing market’s rebound.

articles.headline: Car Sharing Grows With Fewer Strings Attached
articles.snippet: Car-sharing services that don’t require users to return a vehicle to a lot are already popular in Berlin and have now come to many cities in the United States.
articles.abstract: Car-sharing services that don’t require users to return a vehicle to a lot are already popular in Berlin and have now come to many cities in the United States.
articles.lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Marc Clemens, founder and chief executive of Sommelier Privé, an online wine service, gave up owning a car a year and a half ago. When he wants to drive to work in the morning, he checks his smartphone to see where a particular BMW, Smart car or Mini is parked and takes it.

articles.headline: Greek Plan May Reward Some Bank Executives
articles.snippet: Many of the investors who are expected to participate in the stock program are the same executives who were running the banks at the time of their crisis.
articles.abstract: Many of the investors who are expected to participate in the stock program are the same executives who were running the banks at the time of their crisis.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — Even as European taxpayers grimace at the escalating cost of bailing out Greece’s banking system, the banks’ top executives are poised to potentially strike it rich.

articles.headline: Royal Bank of Canada Gains by Putting the Brakes on Traders
articles.snippet: The bank has made inroads with a technology that it says delays trades just enough to defuse the advantages sought by high-speed traders.
articles.abstract: The bank has made inroads with a technology that it says delays trades just enough to defuse the advantages sought by high-speed traders.
articles.lead_paragraph: The spoils on Wall Street generally go to the firm that is the fastest and most opaque. But one upstart contender is trying a distinctly counterintuitive approach.

articles.headline: Chinese Investors Pursue U.S. Property Deals
articles.snippet: Chinese investors have been buying marquee commercial properties in New York and other American cities, in many cases encouraged and aided by the Chinese government.
articles.abstract: Chinese investors have been buying marquee commercial properties in New York and other American cities, in many cases encouraged and aided by the Chinese government.
articles.lead_paragraph: First, it was the Japanese. Moneymen from Tokyo blew into the United States to buy famous pieces of the American landscape, from Rockefeller Center in New York to the Pebble Beach Golf Links in California.

articles.headline: Taliban’s Divided Tactics Raise Doubts Over Talks
articles.snippet: Members of the Taliban’s newly opened office in Qatar have been talking about making peace with the Afghan government, but some Western observers remain skeptical.
articles.abstract: Members of the Taliban’s newly opened office in Qatar have been talking about making peace with the Afghan government, but some Western observers remain skeptical.
articles.lead_paragraph: DOHA, Qatar — When the Taliban opened their political office in Qatar last week, stepping into the halogen glare of TV cameras, it was the first time in a dozen years that the world had gotten to see members of the insurgents’ inner circle — and they seemed different. Urbane and educated, they conducted interviews in English, Arabic, French and German with easy fluency; passed out and received phone numbers; and, most strikingly, talked about peace.
articles.byline: By Rod Nordland and Alissa J. Rubin

articles.headline: Dropping Out of College, and Paying the Price
articles.snippet: College graduates have higher employment rates and make more money, but many students drop out because the cost of college seems to be more than their job prospects are worth.
articles.abstract: College graduates have higher employment rates and make more money, but many students drop out because the cost of college seems to be more than their job prospects are worth.
articles.lead_paragraph: David Beltrán has a solid understanding of the benefits of a college education. The 22-year-old from Queens — a journalism major at Brooklyn College — has seen too many friends drop out only to find themselves working at a fast-food counter or at a construction job. “They are getting by, but they are not very happy.”

articles.headline: Beyond Black and White, New Force Reshapes South
articles.snippet: Despite the Supreme Court’s ruling on voting rights, a temptation to gerrymander districts could harm the G.O.P.’s long-term prospects.
articles.abstract: Despite the Supreme Court’s ruling on voting rights, a temptation to gerrymander districts could harm the G.O.P.’s long-term prospects.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Deep South was, quite literally, a black and white world in 1965, when Congress approved the Voting Rights Act, sweeping away barriers that kept African-Americans from the polls.

articles.headline: Supreme Court Bolsters Gay Marriage With Two Major Rulings
articles.snippet: The court ruled unconstitutional a 1996 law denying federal benefits to legally married same-sex couples and effectively permitted gay marriage in California.
articles.abstract: The court ruled unconstitutional a 1996 law denying federal benefits to legally married same-sex couples and effectively permitted gay marriage in California.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In a pair of major victories for the gay rights movement, the Supreme Court on Wednesday ruled that married same-sex couples were entitled to federal benefits and, by declining to decide a case from California, effectively allowed same-sex marriages there.

articles.headline: Wearable Devices Nudge You to Health
articles.snippet: Tracker devices like Fitbit and Up keep you aware of your inactivity and lack of sleep, and motivate you to put your life onto a healthier track.
articles.abstract: Tracker devices like Fitbit and Up keep you aware of your inactivity and lack of sleep, and motivate you to put your life onto a healthier track.
articles.lead_paragraph: You’ve heard of the Quantified Self movement? It’s the rise of watches, clips and bracelets that monitor your physical activity, sleep and other biological functions. The idea is that continual numerical awareness of your lifestyle works to motivate you: to park farther away, to get off the subway one stop sooner, to take more stairs. You study the graphs, you crunch the numbers, you live a longer, healthier life. (And you try to avoid being a crashing bore at parties.)

articles.headline: Court Follows Nation’s Lead
articles.snippet: Rulings that would have once loomed as polarizing instead underscored vast changes across the country.
articles.abstract: Rulings that would have once loomed as polarizing instead underscored vast changes across the country.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — When proponents of same-sex marriage decided nearly five years ago to bring their legal battle before the Supreme Court, the decision set off a spasm of anxiety among many gay leaders worried that an adverse ruling would set back a fight that many of them had never really wanted.
